T H E
L I F E A N D A D V E N T U R ES
T H E
Yºº Was born at York, in the year 1632, of
I * , a reputable family. My father was a na-
T H E
T H E
tiful fortune. He married my mother at York, who
T H E
T H E
T H E
T H E
T H E
T H E
was a lieutenant-colonel in Lockhart's regiment, but
T H E
could never learn.
No charge nor pains, were wanting in my educa-
T H E
T H E
T H E
and the intreaties of friends. One morning my fa-
T H E
T H E
T H E
T H E
T H E
T H E

mor
2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.

ing our condition by wandering abroad, were fur-
rounded with mifery and danger, and often ended
2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.
2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.
2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.

mal eloquence, while floods of tears ran down his

2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.

2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.
I was then, I think, nineteen years old, when one
2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.
2 R O B I. NS O N C R U S O E.
to London; and acquainting him with my wandering

their anchors, were forced out to the mercy of the
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.

cry out, She would fºunder words I then was igno-
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
his men went to prayers, expecting death every mo-
ment. In the middle of the night one cried out, We
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
when immediately all hands were called to the pump;
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
with them in their labour. While thus employed,
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
Even in that common condition of woe nobody mind-
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
thinking me dead, and it was a great while before I
recovered.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
our pumping had been in vain, and vain had all our
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
buoy to it, which after great labour they got hold of:
and we hauling them to us, got into their boat, and
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
than a quarter of an hour ; and thus I learned what

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
happily effected, landing at a place called Cromer, not
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
either to Hull or London.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
I did not return to my father; who, hearing et the
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
When we had been at Yarmouth three days, I met
my old companion, who had given me the invitation
to go on board along with his father. His behaviour
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
how I had made this voyage for a trial only to pro-
ceed farther abroad. Upon which the old gentleman.

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.

ly my duty; but as you have made this voyage for a trial,

6. R O B I N S O N C R U S o E.
6. R O B I N S O N C R U S o E.

made towards the boat; upon which I took out a

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 9
the boy Xury, I perceived he trembled at the action;
but I put him out of all fear, telling him, that if he
would be true and faithful to me, I would do well by

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 9

think me gone to the Strait's-mouth, 1 kept to the

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. I i

The place I was in was no doubt that wild coun-
try, inhabited only by a few, that lies between the
Emperor of Morocco's dominions and the Negroes.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. I i
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. I i

I 2 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
I 2 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.

beginning to flow, we lay ready to go further in, but

we had rowed, or rather were driven about a league
and a half, a raging wave, like a lofty mountain,
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
towed up in a moment, we had hardly time to call
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
plore, in dying ejaculations, his infinite mercy to re-
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
gling in the pangs of death ; but while I was over-
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
of time, as it were, between life and death. I was
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
gulf unknown, and as yet unperceived, never to be-
hold my friends, nor the light of this world any more!
Could I even have thought of annihilation, or a total
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
thoughts of having no further being, no knowledge
of what we hoped for, but an eternal quietus, without
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
companions were overpowered and intombed in the

To the 14th of this month, my time was employed
in making voyages, every tide getting what I could out
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
Oétob. 25. It blew hard, and rained night and day,
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
ther. -
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
place cºnvenient for my abode. I fixed upon a rock
in the evening, marked out a half moon, intending to
erect a wall, fortified with piles, lined within with
pieces of cables, and covered with turf. -
Nov. 1. I erected my tent under a rock, and took
up my lodgings very contentedly in a hammock that
night.
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
which were good to eat, and in the afternoon made
me a table. - -
Nov. 4. I began to live regularly. In the morning
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
my gun ; I then worked till near eleven o’clock;
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
to eat. From twelve to two I would lie down to
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
to work again. - -
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| my return I perceived many wild birds, and was terr
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .

omitted the 13th, which according to my calculation,

no fit returned the next day, which was the 29th,
Ro BIN so N c R U so E. 43
The 30th, I went abroad with my gun, but not far,
Ro BIN so N c R U so E. 43
which, however I cared not to eat when I brought
then home, but dined on two more of the turtle’s
eggs. In the evening I renewed my medicine, ex-
Ro BIN so N c R U so E. 43
ther did I chew the leaf, or hold my head over the

R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
and that was an earthen pot, not only to hold my
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
could do. It once happened, that as I was putting
out my fire, I found therein a broken piece of one of
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
having no notion of kilns, or of glazing them with
lead, I fixed three large pipkins, and two or three pots
in a pile one upon another. The fire I piled round
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
all; and when I perceived them perfeótly red, I let
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
- till the clay melted by the extremity of the heat, and
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
bated; and watching them till the morning, I found

I waited there till evening, when the time of ebb be-
ing made, I plainly perceived from the rock the cur-
rent again as before, with this difference, that it ran
7, Ro B 1 N so N C R U so E.
7, Ro B 1 N so N C R U so E.
hurrying me and my canoe along with it, which at
another time it would not have done. And now

they brought with the women, and who proved very

were loaded with a large quantity of bread, and rice

218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
bounds, where at this day they quietly and happily re-
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
are confined to a neck of land about a mile and a
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
lofty mountains behind them, free from the appear-
ance of canoes; and indeed their countrymen have
never made any enquiry after them. We gave them
twelve hatchets, and three or four knives; have taught
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
make bread, breed tame goats, and milk thern, as
like wife to make wicker works, in which, I nouft ins
218 R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.

nothing but wives to make then a nation. . .

Wife No; great old Benamuckee god is in my
country, not yours.

Yºº Was born at York, in the year 1632, of
I * , a reputable family. My father was a na-
T H E

tiful fortune. He married my mother at York, who

could never learn.

his men went to prayers, expecting death every mo-

4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
when immediately all hands were called to the pump;
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
with them in their labour. While thus employed,
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.

4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.
thinking me dead, and it was a great while before I
recovered.

4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.

4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.

4 R O B J N S O N C R U S O E.

either to Hull or London.

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
When we had been at Yarmouth three days, I met
my old companion, who had given me the invitation
to go on board along with his father. His behaviour
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. – 5.
how I had made this voyage for a trial only to pro-

The place I was in was no doubt that wild coun-
try, inhabited only by a few, that lies between the
Emperor of Morocco's dominions and the Negroes.

day eighth year I left my father and mother in York--

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
we had rowed, or rather were driven about a league
and a half, a raging wave, like a lofty mountain,
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
towed up in a moment, we had hardly time to call
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
plore, in dying ejaculations, his infinite mercy to re-
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
gling in the pangs of death ; but while I was over-
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
of time, as it were, between life and death. I was
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
gulf unknown, and as yet unperceived, never to be-
hold my friends, nor the light of this world any more!
Could I even have thought of annihilation, or a total
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
thoughts of having no further being, no knowledge
of what we hoped for, but an eternal quietus, without
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
companions were overpowered and intombed in the
deep; and it was with great difficulty I kept my
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
buried me at once twenty or thirty feet deep, but at
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 19.

the return of the wave, which, no doubt, would then
2 C. R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
2 C. R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.
2 C. R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.

take me, I reached the main land, where clamberings
2 C. R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.

foaming ocean. ... --
2 C. R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.

like a reprieve to a dying malefactor, with the halter

To the 14th of this month, my time was employed
in making voyages, every tide getting what I could out
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
Oétob. 25. It blew hard, and rained night and day,
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
ther. -
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
place cºnvenient for my abode. I fixed upon a rock
in the evening, marked out a half moon, intending to
erect a wall, fortified with piles, lined within with
pieces of cables, and covered with turf. -
Nov. 1. I erected my tent under a rock, and took
up my lodgings very contentedly in a hammock that
night.
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
which were good to eat, and in the afternoon made
me a table. - -
Nov. 4. I began to live regularly. In the morning
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
my gun ; I then worked till near eleven o’clock;
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
to eat. From twelve to two I would lie down to
| R O B I. NS ON - C R U S O E. 3 .
to work again. - -

July 19. Having prepared two bags, I returned
46 R O B I N so N c R U S O E.
46 R O B I N so N c R U S O E.
46 R O B I N so N c R U S O E.
thereabouts. To prevent this happening again, I

keep them unhurt, and that they might cure and dry
46 R O B I N so N c R U S O E.
lines and lemons, I returned once more to my old

Aug. 3. Perceiving my grapes to be dry, I took.
them from the trees, and they proved excellent good.

Aug. 14. This day it began to rain; and though I
had made me a tent like the other, yet having no hel-

hind me to retreat to, I was obliged to return to my



ral days. -

R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
could do. It once happened, that as I was putting

R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
having no notion of kilns, or of glazing them with

R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
all; and when I perceived them perfeótly red, I let
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57

R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
R O B J N S O N C R U S O E. 57
bated; and watching them till the morning, I found
I had three very good pipkins, and two earthen pots,

6o R O B I N S O N C R U S O E.

through a long lañe, to the village where we were to
------------------~~~~~~~~~~

fet, we came into the plain, which was not above two. "
furlongs over, and then we perceived five great wolves,
------------------~~~~~~~~~~
------------------~~~~~~~~~~

------------------~~~~~~~~~~

day fain would have fired at them, but I would not:
permit him; nor had we gone half over the plain,

R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
time we were in the road of Bengal, where, going on
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
I was preparing to go on board, one of the men came to
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
*ed him not to carry me on board any more. This info-
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
cargo, intreating him to go on board, and by acquaint-
ing the captain with it, prevent the mutiny which I
perceived would happen. But before I had º:
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
R O B I N S O N C R U S O E. 256
carpenter, and all the inferior officers, came to the

round with large ones, to keep out pilfering thieves,
